checkpoint-1.caption: Students can access presentation information regardless of their sensory abilities.

table.task: Add alternative text to images, charts, SmartArt, and other visual elements. (distributed files only)
Use actual text instead of images of text or text in logos. (distributed files only)
Create accessible data tables with proper headers and avoid merged cells. (both presentations & distributed files)
Add closed captions to embedded video content. (both)
Provide transcripts for audio elements. (distributed files only)
Use high contrast color combinations for text and backgrounds. (both)
Don't rely solely on sensory inputs such as color, shape, size, visual location, or orientation to convey meaning. (both)
Use readable fonts with appropriate size. (both)
Use PowerPoint's built-in slide layouts and heading styles. (both)
Include speaker notes with descriptions of visual content for screen reader users. (distributed files only)

checkpoint-2.caption: Students can navigate and use the presentation regardless of their physical abilities.

table.task: Ensure all interactive elements can be accessed with keyboard navigation. (distributed files only)
Create a logical reading order for slide content using the Selection Pane. (distributed files only)
Avoid using automatic slide timings that can't be adjusted. (distributed files only)
Add descriptive hyperlink text so that the link's funciton can be understood the first time it is read or heard. (distributed files only)
Consider including a table of contents or agenda slide with links to sections when more than X slides. (distributed files only)
Avoid content that flashes more than three times per second. (distributed files only)
Make interactive buttons and controls large enough for those with motor difficulties. (distributed files only)

checkpoint-3.caption: Students can easily understand presentation content and predict how to use controls.

table.task: Set the presentation language in the properties panel. (distributed files only)
Mark foreign language phrases when they appear in content. (both presentations & distributed files)
Use consistent navigation and layout across slides. (both)
Keep slide content concise with one main idea per slide. (both)
Use simple language and define technical terms or acronyms. (both)
Provide clear instructions for any interactive elements. (distributed files only)
Create a slide title for each slide that describes its content. (both)

checkpoint-4.caption: Students can access the presentation using different technologies and tools that help them learn.

table.task: Run the Accessibility Checker before finalizing the presentation. (presentations & distributed files)
Consider providing presentations in alternative formats (e.g., PDF, HTML). (distributed files only)
